title: Dangers of Poor Sleep
content: Different stages and cycles of sleep, including what is referred to as the 4 pillars of sleep, contribute to memory consolidation and numerous important pathways to mental health. Chronic sleep deprivation can lead to serious health issues such as the development of dementia. Acute dangers of sleep deprivation include fatal car crashes which are most often caused by drowsy driving. The different and important roles of REM vs. non-REM sleep are also discussed, as well as the impact that bad sleep habits can have specifically on those sleep stages.

title: Sleep & Covid-19
content: The relationship between sleep and immune function is discussed, along with the impact of sleep on chronotypes and hygiene tips.

title: Sleep Strategies
content: Strategies for sleeping more and sleeping better are discussed, including dealing with issues such as sleep apnea and creating an optimal sleep environment.

title: Sleep and Health Topics
content: Various health topics related to sleep are discussed, including fasting, gut health, blue light, caffeine, and REM sleep.

title: Optimizing Brain Health: Alzheimer's Disease Risk Factors, APOE, Prevention Strategies

Chronic sleep deprivation can lead to the development of dementia, and more acute dangers of sleep deprivation like fatal car crashes which are most often caused by drowsy driving. The different and important roles of REM vs. non-REM sleep, and the impact that bad sleep habits can have specifically on those sleep stages.

Sleep and Alzheimer's Disease
content: Sleep disruption could be a biomarker of dementia, or even an underlying cause. Sleep may be one of the most significant lifestyle factors that determines your risk ratio for Alzheimer's disease. Poor sleep could lead to neuronal energy deprivation. Insufficient sleep increases oxidative stress leading to a cascade of events that lead to neuronal death. The hippocampus, which is involved in memory, is the first area damaged in Alzheimer's. During deep sleep, the brain's 'sewage' system, the glymphatic system, kicks in and washes out 'metabolic detritus' of wakefulness. One of the things washed away is β-amyloid, a core protein in Alzheimer's formation which escalates Alzheimer's risk.

title: Alzheimer's and Sleep
content: Alzheimer’s is a complex disease with genetic predisposition and multiple pathways driving injury to a very sensitive organ. In the future, there may be at least 5 subtypes of Alzheimer’s. Data suggests that tau accumulation, a factor in Alzheimer's, can result from sleep insufficiency. The strong predictive link between insufficient sleep and Alzheimer's disease suggests that different sleep features will be predictive of different aspects of the amyloid pathology cascade. Poor sleep has many negative health effects that could feed into Alzheimer's disease, making it difficult to tease out mechanistic links.

title: Sleep Quality and Alzheimer's Risk
content: Research indicates that the quality and quantity of sleep at different stages of life can predict the levels of β-amyloid and tau in the brain later in life, proteins associated with Alzheimer's disease. Sleep deprivation in different decades seems to be linked to an increase in β-amyloid versus tau. If you're getting less sleep at almost any point in the lifespan, the risk that you're going to have higher amounts of these Alzheimer's disease proteins in your brain is greater.

title: The Importance of Sleep
content: Sleep is crucial for health, with regularity, continuity, quantity, and quality being the four pillars of sleep. Poor sleep can lead to many health issues, including cardiovascular disease and impaired glucose disposal, both of which affect the brain. Getting sufficient sleep is one of the best preventative actions against Alzheimer's disease. Sleep is also essential for memory processing and learning. Insufficient REM sleep can lead to increased mental health issues such as anxiety, depression, and suicidality.

title: Stages of Sleep
content: Humans have two stages of sleep: Non-REM and REM. Non-REM has four stages, with stages 3 and 4 being the deep restorative stages and stages 1 and 2 being the lightest stages of sleep. The brain cycles between non-REM and REM sleep every 90 minutes. The ratio of non-REM to REM changes across the night, with the majority of the 90-minute cycle being deep non-REM in the first half of the night and the majority of the cycle being REM in the second half of the night.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Health Risks
content: Sleep deprivation can lead to a quick reduction in health, with potential risks including cancer, mental health issues, cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome, and suicidality. In terms of de-risking just about every disease that is killing us in the developed world, it’s very hard to look no further than sleep. Nutrition and exercise are important, but sleep is the foundation on which those two other things sit.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Health
content: Sleep deprivation is dangerous and can be deadly. In the 1983, rats were deprived of sleep until they died, dying 20% sooner than they did from starvation. There is also a condition in humans called fatal familial insomnia, which is strongly heritable and results in death in 18-24 months. There is some degree of proof that insufficient sleep is fatal in human beings.

title: Effects of Sleep Deprivation on Driving
content: Lack of sleep can lead to deadly car crashes. Drowsy driving accounts for more accidents on our roads than either drugs or alcohol combined. Microsleeps, small lapses where the eyelid will partially close, are common in sleep-deprived individuals and can lead to fatal accidents.

title: Sleep Stages and Health
content: Your brain has different taste sensitivities to non-REM and REM across the 24-hour clock face. Early to bed and early to rise and sleeping only 6 hours, it means you’re losing mostly REM. The type of sleep you get will not be the same if you move your window of sleep to earlier in the day (short changing REM sleep) or to later in the night (short changing deep non-REM).

title: Importance of Sleep
content: Sleep has been stigmatized as laziness, but it is crucial for health. Chronic diseases like Alzheimer’s are linked to lack of sleep. There is no physiological system in the body, and there is no operation of the brain that isn’t wonderfully enhanced by sleep when you get it, or demonstrably impaired when you don’t get enough.

title: Sleep and Performance
content: Sleep can be a tool for optimizing performance. The erosion of sleep time has hit an all-time high. We are now sleeping less than we have ever done in what seems to be the history of our species. In 1942, the average person slept 7.9 hours per night. Today, the average person sleeps 6 hours and 31 minutes. The decline has not been linear, it is accelerating.
